<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 740, 92]]<|/det|>
The IGCSE class is investigating the position of the image in a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 507, 122]]<|/det|>
A student's ray-trace sheet is shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 144, 845, 816]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 823, 532, 841]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 819, 92]]<|/det|>
The line \(\mathbf{MR}\) shows the position of a plane mirror. \(\mathbf{NL}\) is the normal at the centre of the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 453, 122]]<|/det|>
**AB** marks the position of an incident ray.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 875, 170]]<|/det|>
The student pushes two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) into this line. She views the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 875, 230]]<|/det|>
She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) some distance apart so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and \(\mathsf{P}_3\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and of \(\mathsf{P}_1\), all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are labelled.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 243, 146, 261]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 242, 875, 276]]<|/det|>
Draw in the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it crosses \(\mathbf{MR}\) and extends at least \(8.0 \text{cm}\) beyond \(\mathbf{MR}\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 146, 307]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 875, 323]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the procedure without moving pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) but using a different angle of incidence. On Fig. 4.1, the new positions of pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are marked \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 180, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 875, 369]]<|/det|>
Draw in the line joining the positions \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\). Continue the line until it extends at least \(8.0 \text{cm}\) beyond \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 381, 180, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 781, 91]]<|/det|> The IGCSE class is determining the mass of a load \(\mathbf{X}\) using a balancing method. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 363, 121]]<|/det|> Fig. 5.1 shows the apparatus. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 128, 863, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 288, 534, 306]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 319, 645, 338]]<|/det|> The centre of the load \(\mathbf{X}\) is fixed at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 350, 875, 384]]<|/det|> A student uses a range of values of the mass \(m\) and determines the distance \(d\) from the pivot where the mass must be placed to balance the rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 381, 425, 400]]<|/det|> The readings are shown in Table 5.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 412, 541, 429]]<|/det|> Table 5.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 440, 645, 597]]<|/det|>
\(m/\mathrm {g}\)\(d/\mathrm {cm}\)
4030.2
5023.9
6020.0
7017.1
8015.1
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 615, 146, 632]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 845, 632]]<|/det|> Calculate the distance \(x\) between the centre of the load \(\mathbf{X}\) and the centre of the rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 680, 875, 697]]<|/det|>
